column4: Hi, I'm trying to install ubuntu via boot from usb pendrive. It copied the files okay, when I boot it gets as far as saying Isolinux, then restarts to the boot splash. Anyone know what could be wrong? I've tried using testdisk in windows, which shows the drive as having 4 bootable partitions.
try unetbootin
unetbootin
use unetbootin
why is changing the program used to install a boot loader going to fix the partition structure of the usb disk? I don't see the connection.
oh. right. you should format that usb thing to just fat32.
i forgot unetbootin doesn't do partitioning
It is fat32 now
but just one or a few?
I get from testdisk: bad relative sector, bad starting sector, bad ending sector (chs and lba don't match) only one partition must be bootable.
do you have anything you want to keep on that usb drive?
no.
are you currently in windows?
yes
Is there something i can do in testdisk to fix the drive?
the drive is fine, just have to repartition it.
xp, vista or 7?
http://windows.microsoft.com/en-US/windows7/Can-I-repartition-my-hard-disk
do that but select the usb drive and just make it so there's one big fat32 partition
I already did that it appears in windows as 1 fat32 primary partition. in testdisk however it shows 4 different type partitions.
testdisk is designed to look for deleted stuff, so that might be fine. in windows does it have a free space amount that is about the same as the size of the usb drive?
it shows 14.8 gb for a 16gb device.
close enough. unetbootin will work with that fine
